Ye distant dishes, sideboards blest</br>With Halford's peptic pill—</br>Where grateful gourmands still attest</br>Illustrious Robert's skill;</br>And ye that, girt with legumes round,</br>Or in the purest pastry bound,</br>On silvery surface lie;</br>Where pate — salmi — sauce tomate,</br>Fricandeau framed with nicest art</br>Attract the glist'ning eye.

Ah!  richest scent!  perfume beloved!</br>Blest odours breathed in vain—</br>Where once my raptured palate roved,</br>And fain would rove again.</br>I feel the gales that now ascend,</br>A momentary craving lend—</br>As curling round the vapours seem</br>My faded faculties t' excite,</br>Restore my long-pall'd appetite,</br>And soothe me with their steam.

Say, Monsieur Ude, for thou hast seen</br>Full many a jovial set</br>Discoursing on la bonne cuisine,</br>In social union met—</br>Who foremost now prepare to pray</br>Des cotelettes a la chicoree?</br>Saute de saumon — qui l'attend?</br>What young Amphitryons now vote</br>Nothing like pigeons en compote,</br>Or taste the vol-au-vent?

While some at lighter viands aim,</br>And towards digestion lean,</br>Poularde aux truffes, or a la creme,</br>Or agneau aux racines;</br>Some hardier epicures disdain</br>The distant chance of doubtful pain,</br>And queue d'esturgeon try;</br>Still as they eat they long to cease,</br>They feel a pang as every piece</br>Passes their palate by.

But lo!  the entrements are placed</br>To greet the gourmand's nose,</br>Bedeck'd with all the pride of paste,</br>Confective prowess shows.</br>One earnestly devotes his praise</br>To beignets a la lyonnaise,</br>Others survey with mix'd delight</br>Gelee's d'orange — de marasquin;</br>While some, with looks ecstatic, scan</br>The souffle's buoyant height.

Best fare is theirs by — fed,</br>Less pleasing to digest;</br>The taste soon gone, and in its stead,</br>Oppression on the chest.</br>Theirs joyous hours, and jocund nights,</br>Wit's playful sallies, fancy's flights,</br>And goodly cheer as e'er was seen—</br>The aged Hock — the Champagne bright,</br>Burgundia's best, and Claret light,</br>The vintage of nineteen.

Alas!  regardless of their doom</br>Each rich ragout they take,</br>No sense have they of pains to come,</br>Of head or stomach-ache.</br>Yet see how all around them press,</br>Th' attendants of each night's excess;</br>Fell Indigestion's followers vile:</br>Ah!  show them where the hateful crew</br>Scoff calomel and pills of blue,</br>Ah!  tell them they have bile.

These shall the Gout tormenting rack,</br>The Vampire of the toes,</br>Night-mare, Lumbago in the back,</br>And Cholic's painful throes;</br>Or languid liver waste their youth,</br>Or caries of a double tooth,</br>Its victim's nerves that nightly gnaws.</br>Vertigo — Apoplexy — Spleen,</br>The feverish hand — the visage green,</br>The lengthen'd lanthorn jaws.

This, a consomme, precious prize!</br>Is tempted now to try;</br>To restless nights a sacrifice,</br>And dire acidity.</br>Till throbs of heart-burn — ague's pangs,</br>And Cholera's fiercely-fixing fangs,</br>Have left him, liverless, to moan,</br>The bloated form — the pimpled face,</br>The tottering step — th' expiring trace</br>Of good digestion gone.

To each his twitches, all are men,</br>Condemned to pick their bone;</br>The poor man in another's den,</br>The rich man in his own.</br>Yet, why should I of torments treat?</br>Since we were made to drink and eat,</br>Why should I prophesy their pain?</br>Stomachs were form'd for holding food—</br>No more — while our digestion's good,</br>'Tis folly to abstain.</br>
